reviews.review_msg: I think he has changed the way he teaches by A LOT! I started doing better in the class when I focused on his lecture slides which saved so much time from the textbook. He practically gives you everything you should know/study for the exams on the modules provided.

Class itself honestly isn't that bad. I found that making notes for the textbook and watching the lecture slides after really helped to cut down what you needed to know. However, I found that assignments were graded very harshly and marks were docked off if you missed even the slightest detail.

Get ready to read 90% of the textbook to do well on assignments and exams. Lecture slides are long and boring. BPK 105 goes into extreme detail about different systems within the human body. TA is a tough grader as well, you'd meet all the criteria on assignment rubrics and still get marks docked for missing something unrelated to the question.

Professor Dill is not a bad prof himself, however, bpk105 coursework is challenging. It is textbook-heavy, to Ace exams you practically have to memorize everything on the pages of the textbook assigned. If you aren't good with memorization, I wouldn't recommend it. The topics go into EXTREME DETAIL about each of the body systems! not an elective!!!

Very tough course. It starts off easy then gets really hard.. don't bother watching his lecture recordings because they're boring, repetitive and super long. I learnt way more from teaching myself the learning outcomes using youtube lol. Assignments are also really easy if u understand. I averaged 100% on them and it's 20% of the final grade.

I wish he would use lecture slides that were pre-recorded instead of having students learn from a huge textbook.  It felt impossible to learn everything in this course. Please avoid this course if you don't need it. It definitely is not an elective, and should be more straight forward, especially as a 100-level course.
